Award.AwardTitle: MetPetDB: A Database for Metamorphic Geochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
MetPetDB (Metamorphic Petrology Database) is a database and collaboration suite
developed at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute through a previous Geoinformatics grant. MetPetDB is designed for archival of published data for ready access, an access point for researchers and students to the enormous volume of available information, a collaboration tool among researchers working in different institutions, and a source for data analysis and networking interactions among researchers with the ultimate goal of fostering new and innovative science. It provides a first step for a robust cyberinfrastructure in the geosciences where published and unpublished data can be shared with the community, used in research collectively, and curated by its use through selections, comments and references.

In this project, the PIs will develop a number of new and innovative
functionalities to enhance the current system and continue populating it with data to further improve on this vision of a completely new science through the use of cyberinfrastructure. The data model of the MetPetDB system is based on metamorphic samples and subsamples and incorporates seamless integration between sample characteristics, images and chemical analyses as a fundamental design element. This aspect of MetPetDB is unique in the geosciences, and their results have application in other, image intensive, disciplines. Several
hundreds of samples and thousands of chemical analyses are already uploaded to the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The discipline of metamorphic petrology has provided fundamental insights into our understanding of the tectonics of collisional orogenic belts, the thermal structure of the crust, the evolution of mountain belts, and the means by which fluids transport elements in the crust as occurs in the formation of ore deposits. The types of data used in metamorphic petrology include qualitative and quantitative assessment of the types, amounts, compositions, and textural arrangements of the minerals that constitute metamorphic rocks. A small percentage of this basic information is ever published, and what is published is often difficult to obtain without access to a large number of professional journals, and much of these data are lost forever as individuals retire and samples and data are discarded.

            MetPetDB (Metamorphic Petrology Database) was designed from the outset to rectify this situation by providing a repository for data of all types about metamorphic rocks including information about samples (location, rock type, metamorphic grade, mineralogies, textures etc.), images (maps, photographs of outcrops and samples, photomicrographs of mineral associations and textures, chemical maps, SEM images, etc.) and chemistries of minerals (compositions of minerals determined by electron microprobe, for example). MetPetDB was designed to be fully searchable and accessible to anyone with a web browser. Users had options to search for and download data or to upload their own data to be made accessible to others. The vision was to create a living and ever expanding repository that would be useful to researchers in the field of petrology as well as providing a resource for students.

            Development of MetPetDB has been accomplished largely by undergraduate and graduate student workers. Students majoring in computer science have written all of the code to implement the database, implement the APIs to provide access to the database, and create a web-based front end for the database that can be accessed by anyone with a web browser. Students majoring in geology have accomplished the mining, parsing, and uploading of data from over 1200 published articles on metamorphic rocks. The database (MetPetDB.rpi.edu) currently houses over 11,000 samples with over 22,000 chemical analyses and 28,000 images and data are being added continuously.   

            The MetPetDB system is part of a larger Geoinformatics initiative at NSF that will change the way geosciences are conducted. It will facilitate the gathering of information for researchers beginning new projects, permit browsing and searching for data relating to anywhere on the globe, will provide a platform for collaborative studies among researchers anywhere on the planet, will serve as a portal for students beginning their studies of metamorphic geology, and will serve as a repository of the vast quantities of data being collected by researchers globally. There will be a large increase in efficiency and reduction in duplication of effort, all of which will contribute towards more effective use of federal research monies. Most importantly, it will provide a springboard for launching new scientific studies that would have previously been prohibitively expensive or difficult.
